title: Before 30 April 2017, will the U.S. lift sanctions imposed on Russia for cyber activity, the annexation of Crimea, or its actions in Eastern Ukraine?
preds: It seems that more information about Russian intelligence activities against the U.S. will be coming out in the near future. Related OSINT in the news: “The 4 Russia investigations in Congress, explained,” CNN, April 25, http://www.cnn.com/2017/04/25/politics/congress-russia-investigations “A former top NSA lawyer is joining the Senate's Trump-Russia probe,” Business Insider, April 26, http://www.businessinsider.com/april-doss-will-join-senate-intelligence-committee-russia-investigation-2017-4 “Top Pentagon watchdog launches investigation into money that Michael Flynn received from foreign groups,” Washington Post, April 27, https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/checkpoint/wp/2017/04/27/top-pentagon-watchdog-launches-investigation-into-money-that-mike-flynn-received-from-foreign-groups/?utm_term=.b0f7f6fe101e “Carl Bernstein: Flynn is ‘central to what the FBI believes is cover-up,’” The Hill, April 26, http://thehill.com/blogs/blog-briefing-room/news/330612-carl-bernstein-flynn-is-central-to-what-fbi-believes-is-cover “Carter Page: 'I've been the victim of the one of the most horrendous civil rights violations,'” CNN, April 26, http://www.cnn.com/2017/04/27/politics/carter-page-civil-rights-violations-cnntv “Only 28% of Trump voters believe Russia tried to influence the 2016 election,” Business Insider, April 26, http://www.businessinsider.com/only-28-of-trump-voters-believe-russia-tried-to-influence-the-2016-election-2017-4
It's probably too late to jump on the bandwagon, but I've only discovered this one now... No sanctions to be lifted - too unpopular.
This is not a priority for the Administration, especially given that there are plenty of items that are not related to Russia that can dominate the news cycle every day.

Still zero. And it seems that recent information emerging from investigations into Russian intelligence activities in the U.S. will be even more troubling for Americans.  There may be calls for more sanctions or other defensive actions against penetration of U.S. society (and maybe the U.S. government) by Russian intelligence.  Of interest, in the first week of May some important witnesses are scheduled to testify on the Russia investigation. Witnesses include former acting AG Sally Yates and former DNI James Clapper (our "ex-boss" from the good old days of the IARPA-sponsored Good Judgment Project). Related news reports with some useful OSINT: “No sign probes into Russia, Trump campaign will die down,” Associated Press on Austin American- Statesman, April 25, http://www.statesman.com/news/sign-probes-into-russia-trump-campaign-will-die-down/bzix6oZhal03mR8xXdCvHK/ “Lawmakers: Former Trump Security Adviser May Have Broken US Law,” Voice of America, April 25, https://www.voanews.com/a/lawmakers-say-trumps-former-security-advisor-may-have-broken-law/3824989.html “Lawmakers say Flynn did not disclose lobbying and payments from Turkey and Russia,” Los Angeles Times, April 25, http://www.latimes.com/nation/la-na-flynn-lobbying-20170425-story.html “Flynn’s Turkish lobbying linked to Russia,” Politico, April 25, http://www.politico.com/story/2017/04/25/michael-flynn-turkey-russia-237550 “White House blocks Flynn document request,” BBC News, April 25, http://www.bbc.com/news/world-us-canada-39710527 “Poll: 73% Back Independent Probe of Russian Election Interference,” NBC News, April 24, http://www.nbcnews.com/politics/first-read/poll-73-back-independent-probe-russian-election-interference-n750161 “Senate Judiciary sets date for Yates, Clapper testimony on Russia,” Politico, April 25, http://www.politico.com/story/2017/04/25/sally-yates-james-clapper-russia-testimony-schedule-237568

Despite Russia having backed Trump during the presidential race, it seems that tensions between the two nations have not gotten any better.  Indeed, tensions seemed to have escalated.  As such, I rate it highly unlikely that Trump will lift any sanctions on Russia before April 30th.

Still very zero. Recent news reports seem relevant to our awareness of factors surrounding this GJ question: “Trump denies Exxon permission to drill for oil in Russia,” CNN Money, April 21, http://money.cnn.com/2017/04/21/news/companies/trump-exxon-russia-sanctions “U.S. Rejects Exxon Mobil Bid for Waiver on Russia Sanctions,” New York Times, April 21, https://www.nytimes.com/2017/04/21/business/energy-environment/treasury-exxon-mobil-sanctions-waiver.html?_r=0 It seems somewhat odd that Exxon Mobil would ask the Trump administration to waive sanctions for oil deals at this time. Certainly Exxon Mobil would know that this would be an unwise time to make this request, due to various tensions and investigations.  However, it does give the Trump administration an opportunity to deny the request – which could be helpful politically and legally with regard to ongoing U.S. counterintelligence investigations. Other related news reports containing some relevant OSINT: “WATCH: Carter Page confronts CNN report that Russia tried to use him to infiltrate Trump campaign,” Salon, April 22, http://www.salon.com/2017/04/22/carter-page-confronts-cnn-report-that-russia-tried-to-use-him-to-infiltrate-trump-campaign/ Mr. Page seems to be using the tried-and-true methods 1) Deny. 2) Change the narrative. 3) Counterattack. “Reuters: Think Tank Linked To Putin Distributed Plans to Influence U.S. Election,” Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty, April 20, https://www.rferl.org/a/russia-reuters-report-influence-u-s-election-influence-putin/28440730.html “Sources: Russia tried to use Trump advisers to infiltrate campaign,” CNN, April 21, http://www.cnn.com/2017/04/21/politics/russia-trump-campaign-advisers-infiltrate
This isn't even on Trump's Radar

Still zero probability, though it appears Exxon Mobil is requesting the lifting of sanctions on Russia regarding Exxon Mobil projects. Two related news reports: 1) “Exxon Mobil Seeks U.S. Sanctions Waiver for Oil Project in Russia,” New York Times, April 19, https://www.nytimes.com/2017/04/19/business/energy-environment/exxon-mobil-russia-sanctions-waiver-oil.html 2) “Exxon asks Trump administration for waiver from Russia sanctions,” The Hill, April 19, http://thehill.com/policy/energy-environment/329522-exxon-seeks-waiver-from-russia-sanctions Additionally, the counterintelligence investigations underway may ensure that sanctions are not lifted anytime soon -- and there could be calls to increase sanctions. However, with tensions being the way they are, increased sanctions may not happen anytime soon. Three recent news reports related to the investigations: 1) “Exclusive: Putin-linked think tank drew up plan to sway 2016 U.S. election – documents,” Reuters news service, April 19, http://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-russia-election-exclusive-idUSKBN17L2N3 2) “Trump Adviser’s Visit to Moscow Sent the F.B.I. Digging,” New York Times, April 19, https://www.nytimes.com/2017/04/19/us/politics/carter-page-russia-trump.html?_r=1 3) “FBI used dossier allegations to bolster Trump-Russia investigation,” CNN, April 17, http://www.cnn.com/2017/04/18/politics/fbi-dossier-carter-page-donald-trump-russia-investigation

Still zero probability, in my view. The OSINT in news reports and analyses indicates that the U.S. counterintelligence investigation into Russia may turn up very problematic facts and situations. Still zero probability of this due to a number of factors, including the U.S. counterintelligence investigations into Russian activities. Dropping to zero because this isn't happening in the next two weeks.
Not now that Syria is a Tomahawk target.
Approval rating is too low and this is a toxic area for the white house be putting into this.
I can't see this happening in the time frame. There's too much tension with the Syria situation.

Not before April 30, and maybe not for a while under the circumstances of the U.S. counterintelligence investigation into Russian activities penetrating the U.S. The Russia story has died down a bit due to the air strike against the Syrian air base -- but investigators are no doubt still at work: Related news and OSINT:  “Under investigation, chairman of House Russia probe steps aside,” Reuters news service, April 6, http://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-trump-russia-nunes-idUSKBN1781TE “Where are we on the Trump-Russia investigations?” Associated Press on Boston Globe, April 5, https://www.bostonglobe.com/news/nation/2017/04/06/where-are-trump-russia-investigations/Q0qmYnJ31mLphz8VoA6ZUI/story.html “Trump Son-In-Law Failed To Disclose Meetings With Top Russian Officials,” Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty, April 7, http://www.rferl.org/a/trump-son-in-law-kushner-failed-disclose-meeting-top-russian-officials-kislyak-gorkov/28417685.html

With 19-20 days to go this seems very unlikely, especially given the US domestic political climate for all things Russian and the recent decision to bomb Russian ally Syria.
Since yesterday we have 59 reasons backing up zero probability ;-)

No change to my forecast of zero probability on this question. News about the U.S. counterintelligence investigation into Russia seems to continue to be concerning. No change to zero probability before April 30. The situation regarding U.S. counterintelligence investigations into Russian activities and connections seem to be making the lifting of sanctions out of the question at this time -- unless Putin was to withdraw from Crimea and eastern Ukraine. With the current revelations about Trump's relationships with Russia, he cannot afford to lift any of the sanctions without looking like he is trying to help them. He will have to keep them.

Obstruction by the Democratic Party along with negative publicity by the liberal media have dramatically slowed many measures proposed by the Trump administration. There is absolutely no way the administration is going to ease any sanctions toward Russia YET. The obvious backlash that would ensue does not outweigh any benefits at this point, YET.  The April date is too soon to be viable.

It looked like maybe yes at the beginning but now that there's a more aggressive interest in the possible ties with Russia between Trump's inner circle and the elections, he will have to keep those sanctions otherwise he will look as if he also has ties with Russia (which he probably does).
Tillerson said no. However, Jared will have the final say
too much Russia smoke right now. Even if they wanted to I don't think they want to pour gas on the fire for congress.

No way could this be possible given the ongoing investigations into Russian hacking and possible involvement by the Trump administration. It would be the smoking-gun pro-quo that everyone is looking for.

http://www.toledoblade.com/MikeSigov/2017/03/26/Tillerson-snubs-allies-while-failing-to-appease-Putin.html "Mr. Putin’s expectation that once in office, President Trump would deliver on his implied promise to lift the U.S. economic sanctions against Russia. . . .  is not there anymore. "Judging by the recent Russian government-controlled media stories, Russia’s (read Mr. Putin) is disappointed with President Trump seen as bogged down by the media and congressional critics of his pro-Putin attitudes and thus unable to lift the sanctions. "Furthermore, the confirmation by FBI Director James Comey that the agency is investigating whether the members of Donald Trump’s presidential campaign collaborated with the Russian government makes it highly improbable that Mr. Trump would risk a unilateral rapprochement. "While the investigation is ongoing, the only scenario in which he can lift the sanctions is when Russia promises to return Crimea to Ukraine – something Mr. Putin will never do given that the Crimean annexation is wildly popular in Russia. "The irony is that the very fact that Mr. Trump chose Mr. Tillerson — the recipient of Mr. Putin’s “Order of Friendship” award — as the secretary of state was likely seen by the Kremlin as a communication of Mr. Trump’s implied contract with Mr. Putin to lift the sanctions in exchange for helping Mr. Trump getting elected.  As the former chief executive of ExxonMobil, which has vast business interests in Russia, Mr. Tillerson may once have had an excellent rapport with Mr. Putin, but his hands are tied. "Moreover, Mr. Trump’s pronouncements about NATO — Russia’s perceived nemesis — have flipped from calling alliance “obsolete” to vowing support for it. "Finally, out the window go the Russian dreams of a Trump-Putin alliance expected to reshuffle the world order wherein might makes right — the dreams that made the Russian parliament break into applause upon news of Mr. Trump’s election. "Busted expectations are a bad foundation for negotiations. In Mr. Putin’s case, they will make him less likely to believe any U.S. promises, even if they come from the Order of Friendship holder.  In all likelihood, Mr. Tillerson understands that a breakthrough is not feasible and undertakes that visit simply on orders from Mr. Trump.  The latter seeks to appease the increasingly aggressive Mr. Putin, who has been testing him lately.
. . . 
"The only way to successfully negotiate with Mr. Putin is to talk to him from a position of strength. That is best achieved by strengthening our military, political, and economic alliances, notably by standing by the recent promise to support NATO.  One would hope that our Commander in Chief is in a position to do that. Mike Sigov, a former Russian journalist in Moscow, is a U.S. citizen and a staff writer at The Blade. Co

Lift any sanction or lift all sanctions? I would answer a 0% probability for ALL, but a small probability, say 1% that a single sanction might be removed. Reason: why should a business negotiator give away for free something he can put on the negotiating table? Independently from political reasons for sanctions, I would not. The short residual time adds on top.
It's unlikely that the investigation into the Trump administration's ties with Russia will be resolved by then, so lifting sanctions would be an extremely unpopular move, even with House Republicans.
Highly unlikely. If the US does that it will have such a backlash at home and abroad, not to mention Trump's already compromised situation about his contacts with Russia.
While Trump is close with Russia, his administration has bigger fish to fry. It will happen, but probably not until later

If anyone was looking for proof that Trump has been influenced by Russia, lifting the sanctions would cement this view.  He might ease the sanctions, but that does not count as lifting the sanctions, as per the question.  However, Trump has been known to go completely off the rails, signing executive orders like he thinks he has unilateral control.  So I'll give him a slight chance of actually lifting the sanctions, but it still is not likely by any stretch of imagination.
No way! Even if Trump has been said to be positive vis-à-vis Putin, he will not/can't afford to act in favour of him.
Trump is already under the microscope. To remove sanctions would open an entirely new investigation into his Russian connections.

On the one hand, Trump seems to be willing to make friends with Putin, on the other hand he (his administration) is under pressure to prove he has not already been in bed with Putin before the elections, so I guess lifting the sanctions will take some more time.

Russian aggression following the election of Donald Trump shows Russian confidence.  While the last-minute sanctions imposed by the Obama administration may be lifted following a full investigation, it is unlikely the results will conclude Russia did not interfere.  As far as Russian intervention in Crimea, there isn't much wiggle room for the US to adjust sanctions in the presence of the international community.

G7 meet in May - the question for me is whether the US want to sort out their policy on Russia & the Middle-East before that or after. I think domestic policies will take up too much processing power before then, so I see a rapprochement coming out of the G7 at the earliest.

As others have noted, there's a host of issues with Russia right now.  I agree it is a very low probability of either sanctions will be lifted for cyber activity, the annexation of Crimea, or actions in Eastern Ukraine.  Unless there is some amazing, stunning news, I put my initial forecast at 5%.
Can't see this turn around happening within a month.
With all the pressure from Russia related scandals on the Trump administration, probably politically untenable.

While it has been reported in the past that the president has said he would be interested in lifting sanctions as part of a deal to reduce nuclear weapons to gain favor with Putin so business relations can be opened with Russia, it seems there are more forces against doing so. 1. The most vocal proponent within his administration  for lifting sanctions has resigned, Michael Flynn, his former National Security Adviser. 2. Trump's own cabinet members, Secretary of State, Rex Tillerson; Department of Defense, Jim Mattis, and National Security Adviser, H. R. McMaster, are realists and regard Russia's actions in Crimea, Eastern Ukraine, and the cyber attack on Ukraine's power grid as aggression and contrary to international law.  3. A bipartisan group of 18 senators has introduced legislation establishing congressional oversight of Russia sanctions relief through The Russia Sanctions Review Act of 2017, S. 341, which requires that before sanctions relief can be granted the Administration has to submit to Congress certification that the Russian Federation has ceased specific actions in the Ukraine. Another senate bill is S. 94, the Counteracting Russian Hostilities Act of 2017, that has 20 co-sponsors—10 Republicans and 10 Democrats,". The bill to impose sanctions in response to cyber intrusions by the Government of the Russian Federation and other aggressive activities of the Russian Federation, and for other purposes. 4. Both Republican Senator Mitch McConnell and House Speaker Paul Ryan, Republican, have issued stern warnings to  President Trump against lifting sanctions on Russia.  The open question is whether, as Republicans, their opposition to lifting sanctions is strong enough that they would actively work to pass these two bills in opposition to the President if he decides on lifting sanctions. Does President Trump want to risk a public falling out with top Republican leaders in congress? 5. It was reported that Former Ukrainian Prime Minister Yulia Tymoshenko who met with President Trump and Vice President Pence, at the National Prayer Breakfast, Thursday, February 2, 2017, said the President told her that he would not abandon the Ukraine. Ms. Tymoshenko disclosed her private conversation with the President to both the Heritage Foundation and the Hudson Institute.  6. There would be complications if President Trump unilaterally lifts sanctions on Russia.  “If the U.S. were to provide sanctions relief to Russia without verifiable progress on the Minsk Agreements, we would lose all credibility in the eyes of our allies in Europe and around the world,” said Senator Ben Cardin (D-Maryland).  “The United States should not ease sanctions on Russia until Putin abandons his illegal annexation of Crimea, verifiable and permanently ends Russian aggression in Ukraine, and fully implements the Minsk accords,” said Senator Marco Rubio (R-Florida). “Easing sanctions on Russia would send the wrong message as Vladimir Putin continues to oppress his citizens, murder his political opponents, invade his neighbors, threaten America’s allies, and attempt to undermine our elections,” said Senator John McCain (R-Arizona). “Congress must have oversight of any decision that would impact our ability to hold Russia accountable for its flagrant violation of international law and attack our institutions.”
